subject: Art
title: Alla Prima (Direct Painting)
description: Completing a painting in one session while the paint is still wet.

hook.text: Alla prima means 'at the first attempt' ‚Äî painting completed in one session, wet into wet, with no waiting for layers to dry. It's fast, energetic, and produces paintings with a spontaneous vitality that multi-session work often lacks.

buildup.text: Process: block in the big shapes quickly (largest brush, biggest value/color areas first), then refine ‚Äî adding details, correcting colors, adjusting edges ‚Äî all while the paint is wet. Speed prevents overworking.

discovery.text: Alla prima forces decisive brushwork: each stroke must be intentional because reworking wet paint creates mud. This constraint develops confidence. Plan the stroke, commit, and leave it. Three strokes are better than thirty.

twist.text: The Impressionists championed alla prima ‚Äî painting outdoors in one session to capture fleeting light. Monet's haystacks, Sargent's watercolors, and Sorolla's beach scenes all share the energetic spontaneity of direct painting.

climax.text: Set a timer for 60 minutes and complete a small painting (8√ó10 or smaller) of a simple subject. The time constraint forces alla prima thinking: big shapes first, bold strokes, no fussing. Speed is your friend.

punchline.text: Alla prima paintings breathe because the artist didn't suffocate them with overworking. Speed creates life.

quiz.question: What is the primary advantage of alla prima painting?
options: It produces spontaneous, energetic work by forcing decisive brushwork and preventing overworking
